Ron,
I remember that koshirae of course, it was quite interesting and was w=
ell received.  The dates of the period divisions are not exact.  We use thi=
s set of terms for the Edo period =E6=B1=9F=E6=88=B8=E6=99=82=E4=BB=A3:

 =
=E5=88=9D=E6=9C=9F shoki, the first part of the Edo period after Momoyama
=
=E5=89=8D=E6=9C=9F zenki, early Edo

=E4=B8=AD=E6=9C=9F chuki, mid Edo

=E5=
=BE=8C=E6=9C=9F koki, late Edo

=E6=9C=AB=E6=9C=9F baki, latest Edo, Bakuma=
tsu.

The start of late Edo would be around the early 1800's.

Jim




  Hi=
 Jim - 

  Perhaps an obvious answer here, but when a kodogu worksheet stat=
es "late Edo," when does this begin, in the eyes of the Chicago team? 

  Y=
ou may recall the "skull/bones and grave marker" motif koshira of the ko-wa=
kizashi (of my friend) that went through on Saturday. 

  Thanks, 

  Ron
 =
 STL
